text: What <@UUCD6P13J> says, and yes a database. I write the orders to it when they're placed and my logging control then dips in again to update those records with the result whe the market it settled. because logging controls are threaded there's unlikely to be any impact on the performance of your strategies when making calls to  the database, even if it's remote (as mine is).

elements.text: says, and yes a database. I write the orders to it when they're placed and my logging control then dips in again to update those records with the result whe the market it settled. because logging controls are threaded there's unlikely to be any impact on the performance of your strategies when making calls to  the database, even if it's remote (as mine is).

text:
Thanks Peter. I was thinking about this last night after Lee sent his message
I did something similar when I was going down the ML path, ie I was running the backtest against recorded markets and out putting the bits i was interested into a CSV...then into Pandas. -> ML etc
I wasn't quite sure i this was the way to do when running live strategies and if that was the right way of doing it etc
Thanks for the pointers
